Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge unreasonably approved the application despite insufficient and inconsistent evidence of residency

Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency compliance during eligibility period
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship approval set aside; respondent may reapply

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge reasonably assessed the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act subsection 14(5), Federal Courts Act section 21
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's explanation for absences lacked credibility due to memory lapses and lack of documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported absences, oral testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act subsection 14(5), Federal Courts Act section 21
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inaccurate reporting of absences from Canada during the residency period
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence and failure to justify decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Quantitative or qualitative test for residency, with justification required
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Significant discrepancies in the respondentâ€™s reported absences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicants must prove residency through credible evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency compliance during eligibility period
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship revoked; respondent may reapply in accordance with the law
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 571 days out of the required 1,095 days within four years before application; extensive absences from Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement; centralized mode of living test applied but not satisfied
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under Federal Courts Act and Citizenship Act; review by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Family ties, property ownership, duration and frequency of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient physical presence in Canada; lack of compelling evidence to establish a centralized mode of living in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Re Koo test (centralized mode of living test)
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that the Applicant did not meet the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c); no legal or factual errors identified

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was present in Canada for only 584 days within the four years preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on record; no obligation to justify use of physical presence test
Evidence_Used: Record before the Citizenship Judge, including evidence of applicant's establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical presence and residential ties
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or reassessment of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test (quantitative approach) under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the statutory physical presence requirement and properly assessed that the applicant did not meet the 1,095-day residency requirement

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 551 days in the 4-year period preceding application
Traveled frequently between Canada and Colombia
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Evidence_Used: Koo (Re) factors applied to assess centralization of mode of existence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate temporary nature of absences
Credibility_Assessment: Absences found to reflect a structural pattern, not temporary
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence test from Koo (Re)
Decision_Rationale: Frequent and prolonged absences from Canada
Significant personal and economic ties to Colombia
Pattern of absence inconsistent with residency requirement

Application_Facts: Applicants had significant gaps in health card use and extensive international travel; documentation provided was incomplete
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1,095-day residency requirement within a four-year period
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found applicants' evidence insufficient to establish residency
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the refusal decision
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge reasonably concluded that applicants failed to prove they met the residency requirement

Legal_Issue: Whether the appellant meets the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant accumulated 357 days of residence; no exceptions applied
Burden_of_Proof: On the appellant to demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Legal_Rule: Applicant must have at least three years (1,095 days) of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment by citizenship judge
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency due to studying abroad
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of days physically present in Canada: 357

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 691 days over four years; worked internationally; claimed Canada as primary residence under 'centralized mode of existence' test from Re Koo
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge made errors in factual findings (e.g., employment dates, passport stamps); failed to properly apply legal test by comparing residential connections between Canada and other countries
Evidence_Used: Passport stamps, employment records, residency history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate assessment of passport stamps and employment dates
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Decision_Rationale: Original decision was unreasonable due to factual errors and misapplication of the legal test; failure to compare residential ties between Canada and foreign jurisdictions

Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada illegally and sought refugee protection.

Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard required, but RAD applied excessive deference.

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's negative credibility finding reasonable based on inconsistencies in the applicant's testimony?
Outcome: The Federal Court allowed the judicial review, quashed the Board's decision, and referred the matter to a different panel for reconsideration.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found inconsistencies in the applicant's narratives, testimony, and documentation. However, these inconsistencies were minor and peripheral, not affecting central aspects of the claim. The psychologist's report explaining memory issues was inadequately considered.
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution by a gang in Turkey
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review application filed with the Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to adequately consider the psychologist's report on memory issues
Legal_Standard: Credibility findings by the Immigration and Refugee Board are reviewed on a reasonableness standard. Inconsistencies must be rationally related to the applicant's credibility.
Application_Factor: Minor and peripheral inconsistencies in narratives, testimony, and documentation
Decision_Outcome: Negative credibility finding deemed unreasonable; case referred back for redetermination

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the refugee claim based on credibility regarding Baha'i faith and homosexuality
Credibility_Assessment: Board found Mr. Hemmati's claims about Baha'i conversion and homosexuality not credible
Evidence_Type: Lack of sufficient evidence supporting conversion to Baha'i faith and homosexuality
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to Baha'i faith and homosexuality in Iran
Application_Error: Alleged errors in credibility assessment by the Board

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of decision
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case referred back for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Perceived lack of credibility of claimant and supporting letter
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of blood feud in Albania
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of specialized knowledge without notification
Application_Error: Failure to notify applicant before using specialized knowledge
Evidence_Ignored: Authenticity concerns about letter not properly addressed with notice

Crimes.Application_Error: Double-counting of misrepresentation in assessment

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Proper weighing of factors in H&C assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Establishment in Canada, remorse, misrepresentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a different IAD panel

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Decision_Rationale: Board's credibility findings were unreasonable due to reliance on stereotypes and disregard of credible evidence

Dispute_Type: Ownership and inventorship dispute over patents
Legal_Issue: Whether the Court has jurisdiction to reinstate abandoned patent applications and amend the Patent Office Register
Governing_Law: Section 52, Section 73, and Rule 98 of the Patent Act

Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Cloutier must bear his own costs

Outcome_on_Merits: Court found no legal basis to extend statutory limits or grant relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of abandonment, failure to act within statutory period

Defendant_Response: Commissioner argued Cloutier could have acted earlier

Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the weight of evidence and interpretation of testimony by the Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on general country conditions over specific testimonies
Decision_Outcome: Officer denied PRRA application based on availability of state protection in Portugal
Relief_Sought: Substantive relief to overturn PRRA denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard unless legal issues are separable
Decision_Rationale: Officer's reasoning was thorough and deferential given expertise; concluded state protection in Portugal was adequate

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of forced marriage; RPD and RAD found lack of credibility; international flight alternative existed
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fear of forced marriage deemed not credible by RPD and RAD
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents (if any), credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish credibility of fear of forced marriage
Credibility_Assessment: RPD and RAD found applicant not credible; RAD applied reasonableness standard
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Decision_Rationale: Credibility concerns and availability of safe country alternative
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted abuse based on social group (gender and age)
Crimes.Threat_Source: Son and societal structures failing to protect
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD failed to properly assess credibility or provide reasons for rejection

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to properly analyze evidence and apply legal guidelines
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Convention refugee definition; Guidelines 4 and 8 apply
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on membership in particular social group (elderly women facing domestic violence)
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of state protection in Lebanon
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RPD dismissed claim citing insufficient evidence and alternative arrangements
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case referred back for redetermination

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk in PRRA
Application_Facts: Applicant provided credible new evidence of domestic violence and honor killing risk in Turkey
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer failed to transparently address all evidence, including contradictory information in state protection reports
Evidence_Used: State protection reports, applicant's evidence on domestic violence and honor killing risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer ignored contradictory evidence within the same reports
Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Protection from removal due to risk of honor killing
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of transparency and failure to consider all relevant evidence
